title: 111_hr1362
content: The Act titled "National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System Act of 2010" establishes a surveillance system for neurological diseases under the Public Health Service Act. The National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System Act of 2010 mandates the Secretary to enhance infrastructure for tracking neurological diseases like multiple sclerosis and Parkinson's disease. This includes creating the National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System to collect data for research purposes. The National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System Act of 2010 requires the collection and storage of information on the incidence, prevalence, demographics, risk factors, diagnosis, and progression markers of neurological diseases in the United States. The National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System Act of 2010 requires gathering data on disease epidemiology, natural history, prevention, detection, management, treatment, and outcomes measures. Consultation with experts in epidemiology and representatives of health associations focusing on neurological diseases is essential. The National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System Act of 2010 requires experts in various fields such as multiple sclerosis, Parkinson's disease, health information technology, clinicians, and research scientists to carry out activities. The Secretary may award grants to public or private nonprofit entities for this purpose. Coordination with other federal agencies is also mandated for sharing information and analysis. The National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System Act of 2010 mandates the Secretary to make information available to federal departments, agencies, and the public. Privacy and security protections must be as stringent as HIPAA laws. A report is required within 4 years. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 4 years on the National Neurological Diseases Surveillance System, including information on data collection, use, and coordination of databases. The term 'national voluntary health association' is defined as a national nonprofit organization with chapters or networks in states throughout the US. Authorization of Appropriations: $5,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2016 to support national voluntary health associations with chapters or networks in states across the US. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 28, 2010.
